In this study, UiO-66 @CeO2 composites was prepared by loading CeO2 nanoparticles on the surface of UiO-66 using precipitation method, and the effect of CeO2 loading on the catalytic direct reaction of CO2 and methanol into dimethyl carbonate (DMC) was investigated. XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, FT-IR, XPS, SEM and TEM were used to investigate the physical and chemical properties of UiO-66 @CeO2. The results showed that the framework structure of UiO-66 benefit the high dispersion of CeO2, while the loading of CeO2 provided more oxygen vacancies, which promoted the capture and absorb of CO2, thus promoted the reaction synergistically. Among which, UiO-66 @CeO2-60 showed best activity, with the highest DMC formation rate of 2.84 mmol·g−1·h−1 (yield: 2.27%) within 4 h of reaction time under the optimum conditions. In addition, the catalyst also showed favorable reusability, maintaining ∼90% of catalytic efficiency with 4 reuse cycles compared the fresh ones. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Dimethyl carbonate CO2 UiO-66 CeO2 Methanol Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the progress of industrial civilization and rapid development of economy, CO2 was massively emitted and has seriously threatened the survival and development of human beings. The problems and risks caused by excessive CO2 emissions have received worldwide attention, consensus on carbon emission reduction was gradually reaching and corresponding efforts was making. Although excess CO2 serious threat human beings, on the other hand, CO2 is a valuable carbon resource. Effective capture and utilization of CO2 for converting it to value-added chemicals, such as methanol, ethanol and dimethyl carbonate (DMC), can not only alleviate various environmental problems caused by greenhouse effect, but also solve social problems caused by energy shortage[1]. Representatively, DMC, which is regarded as the “cornerstone” of green synthetic chemistry, is an important and non-toxic organic intermediate, which is widely used in the field of pesticide, medicine, plastics, dyes, electronic chemicals and food additives[2]. DMC production from CO2 and methanol is regarded to be one of the important ways to the realize the green utilization of CO2 [3,4]. The reaction of CO2 and methanol for DMC production has the advantages of reaction atomic economy and less by-products. However, the reaction is not spontaneous due to the thermodynamic limitations and the activation of CO2 is difficult. Consequently, designing and developing efficient catalysts to overcome the barrier of reaction energy are vitally important, which are the focuses of research in recent decades. Such heterogeneous catalysts as metal oxide, supported heteropolyacids or metals, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been used for the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol. Bian et al.[5] studied the catalytic activity of Cu-Ni bimetal supported on graphite for the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2. Besides, Cu-Ni or Cu-Fe bimetal supported on other types of support have been developed and studied[6–8]. HP3O4 or H3PW12O40 were supported on Ce, Ti, V or their mixed oxides[9–12], and proved to be a kind of efficient catalysts for the formation of DMC. The above research results show that by loading active metal species on the surface of the support, the catalyst with acid-base dual function can adsorb activated methanol and CO2 at the same time, so as to produce more target product. Metal oxides were suitable and widely studied due to their re-dox and acid-base properties. Typically, CeO2 and ZrO2 exhibit good catalytic activity on account of their oxygen vacancy properties and surface acid-base characteristics[13–15]. Wang et al.[16] synthesized nano-CeO2 with four different morphologically by hydrothermal method. Under the reaction temperature of 140 °C and CO2 pressure of 5 MPa, the spindle-shaped nano-CeO2 had the best catalytic activity. They found that the large number of acid-base active sites were the main factor for the high catalytic activity. Zhao et al.[17] used in situ Fourier infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) to study the influence of nano-CeO2 surface with different morphologies on the reaction performance. It is found that rod-shaped nano-CeO2 present the best catalytic efficiency since it has abundant hydroxyl group on the surface, and thus conducive to the formation of bidentate carbonate species. Tomishige et al.[18] demonstrated that ZrO2 catalyst with a surface containing a major monoclinic phase and a small amount of tetra phase lead to the highest yield of DMC (1% at 50 bar in an autoclave at 170 °C). Moreover, CeO2 and ZrO2 were combined, and proved to be a kind of good catalyst attributing to the nature of dual functional group[19]. Chen et al.[20] developed a kind of TixCe1-xO2 supported on honeycomb ceramics, and the catalyst exhibited 24.3% of methanol conversion with 79% of DMC yield without any dehydrating agents. In addition, the addition of Zr4+ to CeO2 could also improve the thermal stability of the catalyst significantly [21]. More recently, MOFs have attracted the attention due to their such characteristics as adjustable metal nods and ligands structure, large specific surface area and diverse structure[22]. Verma et al.[23] firstly use this kind of catalysts for the DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol. They synthesized a series of Ti-based MOFs materials by designing new different ligands, and DMC yield of 16% was obtained by a Ti-based zeolitic thiophene-benzimidazolate framework. Xuan et al.[24] prepared trifluoroacetic acid modified UiO-66 by hydrothermal synthesis method, and found that the conversion rate of methanol and the selectivity of DMC can be improved by the modification of trifluoroacetic acid. The DMC yield obtained at optimum conditions was 0.084%. Subsequently, they prepared anther kind of Zr-based MOFs, MOF-808, and used them in the same reaction[25]. The results showed that MOF-808 exhibits higher catalytic activity (DMC yield of 0.12%) than that of UiO-66, which might attribute to the relatively larger micropore size in MOF-808, leading the reactants easier access to the active site located in the micropore. For the further modification of Zr-based MOFs, Huo et al.[26] developed a cerium doped Zr-based MOFs for this system. The highest yield of DMC obtained by the optimized catalyst could reach 0.295% under the reaction conditions of 140 °C, 11 MPa without dehydrating agent. It was that the doping of Ce atom in zirconium lattice to generate UiO-66 MOFs could increase the acidity and the number of moderately alkali sites effectively, thus improving the catalytic performance. Moreover, the DMC yield could be further improved to 1.216% with 2-cyanopyridine as dehydrating agent. According to previous researches, the catalyst can activate CO2 by providing electrons or vacant orbitals[21,27]. While methanol molecules are usually activated and adsorbed under the action of Lewis acid-base pairs to produce methoxyl species[28,29], which can also contact with lattice oxygen on the surface of the catalyst to generate such substances as CO2 and water, and further converted into target products. Thus, in order to creating suitable number of oxygen vacancies and modifying the acid-base or re-dox properties, the strategies for promoting the catalytic efficiency mainly focus on the morphologies or the combination and doping of same of different types of materials[2]. Considering the nature of CeO2 and Zr-based MOFs catalyst, we hypothesized that the MOFs and CeO2 based composite catalyst, which could possess the integrated properties, might be a promising catalyst for the directly conversion of CO2 and methanol to DMC. In this study, a new kind of UiO-66 @CeO2 composite catalyst was prepared and evaluated for the reaction of methanol and CO2 using trimethyl orthoformate (TMM) as a dehydrating agent. The effect of the loading amount of CeO2 on the physicochemical properties and catalytic efficiencies of the catalysts was investigated by several characterization methods. The best ratio of the composite catalyst was screened, and the relationship between the catalytic activity and properties of them was clarified. Moreover, the effects of reaction parameters on the production of DMC, as well as the reusability of the catalyst were studied. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O) and TMM were provided by Adamas Reagent, Ltd. Analytically pure zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl4), terephthalic acid (BDC), methanol (CH3OH), acetic acid (HAc) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Methanol was dehydrated by 4 Å molecular sieve. 2.2 Catalysts preparation and characterization The defected UiO-66 was prepared according to the reference[30]. In a typical procedure, 1.55 mmol ZrCl4 and 54.25 mmol HAc were dissolved in 60 mL of DMF and then transferred in to a Teflon lining hydrothermal kettle for ultrasonic treatment for 10 min under room temperature. Then, 0.775 mmol BDC was added followed by ultrasonic treated for another 15 min until all the solid was dissolved and mixed uniformly. After the hydrothermal kettle was placed in the oven at 120 °C for 48 h, the solids obtained was centrifuged and washed with DMF and methanol to remove the impurities. Finally, the UiO-66 was obtained by dried at 80 °C. For the preparation of UiO-66 @CeO2, 1 g of the synthesized UiO-66 and certain amounts of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O were firstly dispersed in 50 mL of ethanol under ultrasound condition. Then the suspension was heated to reflux for 2 h, followed by evaporating the solvent and drying at 80 °C to obtain a pale yellow solid. Series of UiO-66 @CeO2 catalysts were obtained by calcined the above solid with a heating rate of 5 °C·min−1 and maintained at 250 °C for 3 h. The catalysts were denoted as UiO-66 @CeO2-x, in which x represented the mass percentage of Ce added based on the mass of the UiO-66. In addition, original UiO-66 (denoted as UiO-66-O in following) was calcined at the same condition and donated as UiO-66-C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku UItima IV instrument with Cu Kα radiation at 50 kV and 30 mA. N2 adsorption analysis was obtained on a Kubo-X1000 (Builder Electronic Technology Co., Ltd) specific area and pore size analysis instrument; CO2 adsorption characterization was conducted on a Micromeritics ASAP2460 instrument. For the N2 and CO2 adsorption characterization, the samples were degassed at 150 °C under vacuum prior to the analysis. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) data was collected on a Bruker TENSOR 27 instrument. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded with a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on a FEI Inspect F50 instrument with an accelerating voltage of 15.0 kV associated by Quanta 250 (Hillsborough, OR, USA). High resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) and energy dispersion spectrum (EDS) was conducted on a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 instrument under 200 kV acceleration voltage. Temperature programmed desorption of methanol and CO2 (methanol- and CO2- TPD) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem1 II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer. After pretreated under a He flow and saturated with methanol or CO2 at room temperature, the temperature of the samples was ramped to 400 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and the desorbed species were monitored by a mass spectrometer and TCD analyzer. Diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra were recorded on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS20 Spectrometer equipped with a liquid nitrogen cooled mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector (ZnSe Window). Spectra were recorded at 4 cm−1 spectral resolution and 60 kHz scanning velocity. Spectra were collect for the adsorption of CO2 at 25 °C and then sweep with N2, and adsorption and conversion of CO2 and methanol at 140 °C (pre-adsorbed methanol followed by CO2). For each test, the catalyst was pretreated at 120 °C for 30 min in 50 mL/min of N2 flow. Then CO2 was co-charged into the detection system with a flow rate of 5/45 mL/min (CO2/N2) for the adsorption of CO2 at 25 °C. For the adsorption and conversion of CO2 and methanol, the catalyst was pre-adsorbed by methanol at 140 °C for 30 min, and then CO2 was fed into. After the spectra remained unchanged (about 15 min), methanol was co-fed by bubbling evaporation with the CO2/N2 mixture with the same flow rate. 2.3 Catalytic reaction procedure The catalytic reaction was conducted in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with magnetic stirring (NSG25-P5-T3-SS1-SV, Anhui Kemi Instrument Co., Ltd). Typically, methanol and TMM were firstly added into the reactor in proportion, in which TMM was a dehydrator. After added into certain amounts of catalyst, the reactor was purged with pressured CO2 for several times in order to displace the air in the reactor, followed by charging to certain pressure of CO2. Then it was heated to the fixed temperature and maintained for certain time. N-propanol was added as an internal standard substance after the reactor was cooled down. The quantitative analysis was conducted on an Agilent 7890 A gas phase chromatography equipped with HP-5 column and flame ionization detector. According to the chromatographic results, the DMC yield and formation rate was defined and calculated with the Eqs. 1 and 2. (1) DMCyield = DMCformed ( mmol ) × 2 Methanoladded ( mmol ) × 100 % (2) DMCformationrate = DMCformed ( mmol ) Amountofcatalyst ( g ) × Reactiontime ( h ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening The effects of Ce loading amounts on the catalytic performance were investigated under the reaction temperature of 140 °C and reaction time of 4 h, the results were shown in Table 1. The UiO-66-C obtained a little bit lower DMC yield than CeO2, and with the formation of UiO-66 @CeO2 catalysts, the DMC yield increased slightly with the mass percentage of Ce added increased from 5% to 30%, as the UiO-66 @CeO2-30 obtained proximity DMC yield with CeO2. While the loading amount of CeO2 increased from 30% to 60%, the formation rate of DMC increased significantly, and reached 2.84 mmol·g−1·h−1 by UiO-66 @CeO2-60. However, when further increased the loading amount of CeO2, the yield decreased slightly. It could be concluded that the composition and structure of UiO-66 @CeO2 could promote the formation of DMC, and proper loading amount of CeO2 on the catalyst also played an important role in the lifting of the catalytic efficiency. In addition, the XPS spectra of O1s and relative content of oxygen vacancy (O’’) for UiO-66 @CeO2 with different loading amounts of Ce shown in Fig. S1 and Table S1 demonstrated that the catalytic efficiency was positively correlated with the oxygen vacancy content to some extent. Combined with the characterization results in the following sections (Fig. 4 and Table 3), it could be concluded that the porosity and pore structure contributed by UiO-66 facilitate the adsorption of CO2, while the oxygen vacancy introduced and adjusted by CeO2 further promoted the adsorption and activation of CO2, thus promoted the conversion of CO2 and intermediates[15,31]. According to the results for catalyst scanning, UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was chosen as the optimum catalyst and used in the following catalytic study. 3.2 Catalysts characterization 3.2.1 XRD characterization Benefited from the excellent thermal stability of UiO-66, the catalysts maintained original crystal structure of UiO-66 after heat treatment during the preparation process, which could be proved by the XRD patterns of the synthesized catalysts shown in Fig. 1. It could be seen that both the UiO-66-O and UiO-66-C, as well as the Ce modified catalysts, presented typical characteristic diffractions of UiO-66 at about 2θ = 7.3°, 8.5° and 23.5°, which were attributed to the diffractions of (111), (002) and (115) lattice faces, respectively[32]. With the loading of Ce, the characteristic diffractions of CeO2 at about 2θ= 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3° [33]appeared in wide shape and became apparent gradually with the increased of loading amounts, while the related diffractions of UiO-66 weakening gradually. 3.2.2 FI-IR characterization Fig. 2 showed the FT-IR spectra of catalyst samples. It could been seen that the UiO-66-C and UiO-66 @CeO2 presented typically infrared absorption peaks at wavelength at ∼1585 cm−1, ∼1390 cm−1 and ∼745 cm−1, which were attributed to the stretching vibration of COO- and Zr-(μ3)-O, respectively[34]. This confirmed that the component and structure of the UiO-66 based catalysts almost unchanged during the synthesize process, thus retaining the catalytic efficiency of UiO-66 for the composite catalysts. The peaks at ∼3670 cm−1 in the spectra of the UiO-66 based catalysts were attributed to the vibration of the μ3-OH in the Zr6 nodes, which could act as Brönsted acid sites for the catalytic reactions[35]. In addition, the typical absorption peaks of CeO2, including peak at ∼1380 cm−1 and ∼505 cm−1 corresponded to Ce-O-Ce and Ce-O respectively[36], presented in the spectra of the UiO-66 @CeO2 catalysts, combined with the previous XRD characterization, indicating the successful construction of the composite catalysts. 3.2.3 Texture properties The N2 adsorption and desorption curves of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 3A. As shown in the figure, UiO-66-C, as a typical MOFs with micro-pores, presented a typical I shape isotherm[37]. With the loading of CeO2, the isotherms of the samples turned to type IV with H4 hysteresis loops, which indicated that meso-pores were formed. Pore size analysis showed in Fig. 3B and Fig. S2 indicated that UiO-66-C possessed partial micro-pores ranging from 0.5 to 1.0 nm, causing by the missing-linker defects in the structure, which was in consistent with the DFT-analyzed and experimental pore size distributions reported in the literatures [24,38]. Combined with the BET surface and pore size data of the catalysts showed in Table 2, it could be seen that with the loading of CeO2, the pores in the range of 0.5–2.0 nm decreased obviously while the volume of the pores decreases slightly, which might be caused by the pore blocking with CeO2. However, the pores in the range of meso-pores increased, which may attribute to the stacking structure between CeO2 and UiO-66 [38]. It was showed obviously in Table 2 that the specific surface area of the UiO-66 @CeO2 decreased gradually with the increase of the loading amounts of CeO2, associated with diameter of pores increased gradually, which was consistent with the results of pore distribution presented in Fig. 3 and Fig. S2. Observation showed that the total specific surface area was decreased caused by the reason that the microporous were decreased, which was in accordance with the analysis for pore size. Moreover, combined with the adsorption and desorption curves shown in Fig. 3A, it can be concluded that the pores of the catalysts are mainly micro-pores with small portion of meso-pores. 3.2.4 XPS characterization The XPS characterization of the catalysts was performed and the results were shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4A showed the Zr 3d spectra of UiO-66-C and UiO-66 @CeO2-60, it could be seen that after the encapsulation of CeO2, the chemical state of Zr on UiO-66 @CeO2-60 surface remained. This result was similar as the reported results in the literatures[24]. Fig. 4B presented the Ce 3d spectra of CeO2 and UiO-66 @CeO2-60, which consist 8 peaks corresponding to Ce 3d spin-orbit doublets. The corresponding peaks of Ce4+ 3d3/2 and Ce4+ 3d5/2 were denoted as (u, u’’, u’’’) and (v, v’’, v’’’), respectively. Other two peaks was denoted as u′ and v′, which were attributed to Ce3+ species[38]. The characterization results implied that + 4 state was the main chemical valence of Ce on the surface of UiO-66 @CeO2-60, while a small number of + 3 state was co-existed. According to the ratio of peak area for u′ and v′ [39], the calculated content and amount of Ce3+ were listed in Table 3. Compared with the CeO2 prepared under same condition without UiO-66, the content of Ce3+ increased, suggesting that interaction of UiO-66 and Ce facilitated the formation of Ce3+ species. Moreover, the actual amount of Ce calculated from XPS data had good coincidence with the data determined by the precursor added in the preparation process. Fig. 4C showed the O 1 s spectra, the peaks at 529.4 eV, 530.1 eV and 531.3 eV, denoted as O’, O’’ and O’’’ respectively, represented the lattice oxygen, adsorbed oxygen and surface oxygen [40]. It can be seen that the distribution of deferent oxygen species changed a lot in the UiO-66 @CeO2-60, compared to UiO-66 and CeO2. Typically, as listed in Table 3, the percentage of O’’ species of UiO-66 @CeO2-60 maintained the same level compared with UiO-66-C, which was much higher than that of CeO2. The Ce 3d spectral results were in good agreement with the O’’ content, which indicated that the UiO-66 @CeO2 structure enhanced the vacancies of surface oxygen. Since the properties of O′’ were positively correlated with the existence of oxygen vacancies and the oxygen vacancies located at the contact interface can trap and convert oxygen-containing gas phase species into active oxygen species [21,41], the catalytic efficiency of the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was improved. 3.2.5 CO2 adsorptive properties The CO2 adsorptive properties of the catalysts observed from isotherms at 25 °C was shown in Fig. 5. It can be seen in the figure that UiO-66-C presented excellent adsorb capacity for CO2 with an adsorptive amount of 25.02 cm³ /g (STP) at 0.1Mpa, which could be attributed to the abundant micro-pores, which was proved by the N2 adsorption characterization. Although CeO2 was not a good adsorb substance for CO2, the composite material UiO-66 @CeO2-60 exhibit excellent adsorb capacity, especially at low relative pressure. The adsorptive amount of UiO-66 @CeO2-60 at 0.1Mpa was 24.88 cm³ /g (STP), just slightly lower compared to that of the unmodified UiO-66-C. This might on account of that the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 could combine the advantages of the rich oxygen vacancy of CeO2 and the microporous structure of UiO-66. It was reported that the properties of oxygen vacancies associated with Ce3+, could allow the acid-base interaction between non-bonding electrons in the O atom of CO2 and them [42]. While many researches studies suggested that the surface oxygen vacancies allowed the O atoms of CO2 inserted into, and formed bent CO2- [21]. CO2 adsorbed preferentially onto the oxygen vacancies from CeO2 under dilute CO2 concentrations, while the physisorption, which depended on the BET surface areas, was continuously carried out with the incensement of CO2 concentrations [43]. Since the BET surface areas of UiO-66-C was much higher than that of UiO-66 @CeO2-60, the CO2 adsorption amount of UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was slightly lower than that of UiO-66-C at higher pressure. Combined XPS and BET characterization, it could be concluded that the oxygen vacancy properties of UiO-66 and CeO2, as well as the large specific surface and pore structure properties of UiO-66 promoted the capture and absorb of CO2, thus promoted the reaction synergistically. 3.2.6 Methanol- and CO2- TPD Fig. 6 showed the methanol- and CO2- TPD for the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6A, CO2-TPD of the catalysts has a wider desorption peak in the range from ∼70 to ∼200 °C, which was due to the removal of bidentate carbonates from the surface of the catalyst[21]. The intensity of the desorption peak of UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was higher than that of the UiO-66-C and CeO2, which might be attributed to the higher specific surface and concentration of oxygen vacancies. The CH3OH desorption curves shown in Fig. 6B showed two peaks centered at ∼100 and ∼250 °C, which were assigned to associative and dissociative adsorption methoxy species of CH3OH, respectively. The intensity of the latter peaks was similar except that the center temperature of UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was a little higher than the that of the others, implying that the stability of chemisorbed methanol on CeO2, UiO-66 and UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was similar[15]. 3.2.7 SEM and TEM characterization The SEM images of UiO-66-C and UiO-66 @CeO2-60 were presented in Fig. 7. As could be seen in the Fig. 7A, the UiO-66-C presented a morphology of transparent and smooth octahedral crystal with a diameter of ∼200 nm, which was in consist with literatures[38,44]. While loading with CeO2, the surface of UiO-66 @CeO2-60 became grainy and rough (Fig. 7B) due to the formation of CeO2 coating. As a consequence, the structure of UiO-66 might be disordered by the CeO2 covering and coating, which was proved by the XRD characterization. TEM images and representative EDX elemental maps of the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 were collected. Compared to the unmodified UiO-66 ( Fig. 8A), the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 presented an obvious and typical core-shell structure as was shown in Figs. 8B and 8C, the UiO-66 crystals basically unchanged and were encapsulated evenly by CeO2. And in accordance with the SEM images, the catalyst showed grainy and rough surface. Meanwhile, in the HR-TEM images presented in Fig. 8B, the (111) and (200) lattice fringes of CeO2 were identified. In addition, EDX elemental maps in Fig. 8D∼8 G showed that about 10–20 nm of CeO2 coating were established and evenly dispersed. 3.2.8 In-situ Infrared Spectroscopy In-situ DRIFTS technique was employed for the investigation of the reaction mechanism for DMC production over UiO-66 @CeO2-60. As shown in Fig. 9A, the IR band at 1008 cm−1 was assigned to the C-O bond[21], while band at 1540 cm−1 was attributed to O-C-O of bidentate carbonate species. In addition, the bands at 1264 cm−1 and 1631 cm−1 also belonged to the bidentate carbonate[45]. The results indicated that the carbonate and bidentate carbonate species were the main species adsorbed on the surface of the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 for CO2 flow at 25 °C. Bands located at ∼2358 and ∼2339 cm−1 revealed the physical absorption of CO2 [46]. Negative bands at ∼2930 and ∼2850 cm−1 indicated that the O-C bond of the carbonate was cleaved, facilitating the formation of formate species[47]. It also could be seen in the figure that the above typically bands increased gradually and reached equilibrium with the prolonging of CO2 adsorption time, and the physical absorption band disappeared gradually with the nitrogen purging, while the other bands maintained, which proved the chemical interaction between with the catalyst and CO2. Fig. 9B showed the spectra of the surface of the catalyst when CO2 and methanol+CO2 were sequentially flowed on the catalyst pre-adsorbed by methanol. It could be seen that the methanol pre-adsorbed catalyst showed bands at 1194, 1053, 1033 and 1010 cm−1, which were assigned to the terminal and bridged methoxy species[48], respectively. With the feed of CO2, the intensity of these bands decreased gradually, and the bands at 1346, 1401, 1454 and 1475 cm−1 assigned to the monomethyl carbonate[27,49] appeared. In addition, when methanol+CO2 was feed, the bands of monomethyl carbonate increased gradually, confirming the reaction between activated CO2 and the methoxy species to yield the final product DMC. Combined the experimental results and literatures[26,48], a proposed reaction route for the DMC formation over UiO-66 @CeO2-60 catalyst was illustrated in Scheme 1. Briefly, the route could be divided into 5 steps: (i) Methanol molecule was absorbed and broke up into methoxy group (-OCH3) and hydrogen ion on the surface of active component. (ii) CO2 inserted into on the oxygen vacancy, which could be considered as a Lewis base site, and then activated (CO2 *). (iii) The oxygen in -OCH3 attacked the carbon in CO2 * and then formed the monomethyl carbonate intermediate. (iv) Another methanol molecule was absorbed and disintegrated into methyl (-CH3) and hydroxy (-OH). (v) The -CH3 was attacked by the oxygen inserted into the oxygen vacancy and finally formed dimethyl carbonate and water. 3.3 Effects of reaction parameters The effects of reaction temperature, reaction time, CO2 pressure and amount of catalyst were investigated using UiO-66 @CeO2-60 catalyst. It could be seen the Fig. 10A that the yield of DMC increased with the increase of reaction time. However, the formation rate was very slow when operated at 100 °C. With the reaction temperature increased from 100° to 140°C, the yield of DMC increased significantly. While with the reaction temperature further increased to 160 °C, the yield and the formation rate decreased. This result shows that increasing the reaction temperature in a certain range was beneficial to the reaction, while the over high reaction temperature led to the decrease of DMC formation, which might attribute to the reason that the increase of temperature was not conducive to the formation of DMC in the perspective of thermodynamics (ΔH Θ 298 K=−27.9 kJ/mol<0)[50]. In addition, the catalytic activity and selectivity might reduce due to structural damage of catalyst and high temperature [26,51]. From the yield and formation rate of DMC consideration comprehensive, 140 °C and 4 h were chosen as the operation conditions for other investigation, at which 2.27% of DMC yield and 2.84 mmol·g−1·h−1 of DMC formation rate was obtained. The effect of CO2 pressure on the formation of DMC was shown in Fig. 10B, as was shown in the figure, the yield increased with the CO2 pressure, and the growth rate gradually increased within the range of 0.5–4.5Mpa. The higher pressure mainly increased the dissolved CO2 in the methanol based liquid phase system, thus promoted formation of DMC. The effect of catalyst amount on the formation of DMC was shown in Fig. 10C. The increase in catalyst dosage, on one hand, provided more catalytic active sites, while limit the mix and mass transfer of systems on the other hand. Thus, although the yield of DMC increased with the increase of catalyst dosage, the formation rate decrease gradually when catalyst dosage was over 0.1 g. As a consequence, 0.1 g of catalyst dosage was chosen for the efficiency of the reaction process. The catalytic efficiency of UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was compared with that obtained by other catalysts reported in the recent literatures, as listed in Table 4. For comparison, experiment was conducted at optimum conditions obtained from the previous section excepted that the reaction time was prolonged to 24 h, and in this case, 9.16% of DMC yield was obtained. As presented in Table 4, the DMC yield and formation rate obtained by UiO-66 @CeO2-60 catalyst was higher or comparable compared with that over similar type of catalyst. Compared to Zr based MOFs, the DMC formation rate was improved under relatively much lower CO2 pressure (4.5 MPa versus 12 MPa)[24,25]. Despite the yield was higher, the DMC formation rate obtained was lower than that by Ce-UiO-66–2[26], which could be attributed to the dehydrating performance of TMM and 2-cyanopyridine agent differs[25,52]. Moreover, UiO-66 @CeO2-60 also showed superiority over the reported Ce or Ce-Zr oxides with higher DMC yield with short reaction time[31,52–54]. Combined with the results of catalyst characterization, it could be concluded the advantages of CeO2 and UiO-66 was combined in UiO-66 @CeO2-60 catalyst, leading such changes as the enlargement of the specific surface area and regulation of oxygen vacancy properties. The high dispersed CeO2 provided more adsorption and catalytic activity sites, as well as the pore structure and unique properties of UiO-66, promoted the reaction process to form DMC. 3.4 Reusability The reusability of the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was evaluated under the optimum reaction conditions obtained above. The catalyst was centrifugal separated and washed with methanol, then dried at 80 °C for each recycle entry. As presented in in Fig. 10D, the DMC formation rate of 4 cycles obtained by UiO-66 @CeO2-60 decreased slightly, which maintained ∼90% of catalytic efficiency compared to that obtained by the fresh ones, indicating that the considerable stability of the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 catalyst. For further investigation, the XRD patterns and the SEM images of the catalyst after used for 1 and 4 cycles were obtained and shown in Fig. 11. Compared to the that of the fresh catalyst presented above, it could be seen that the crystallographic form and the structure of the UiO-66 @CeO2-60 was basically retained during the recycle and reuse process, despite part of the core-shell structure was damaged (Fig. 11B, C). The favorable reusability of the catalyst could be attributed to the excellent hydrothermal stability of the UiO-66[24], as well as CeO2 [55]. 4 Conclusions In this study, UiO-66 @CeO2 was prepared, characterized and showed good catalytic efficiency for the synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2. Based on the characterization results for the catalysts, it was shown that the framework structure of UiO-66 benefit the high dispersion of CeO2, as well as the core-shell structure. Among which UiO-66 @CeO2-60 showed best activity, with a DMC formation rate of 2.84 mmol·g−1·h−1 within 4 h of reaction time under optimum conditions (140 °C and 4.5 MPa CO2). Both integrate and synergistic effects were concluded by the properties and the catalytic performance with proper composition of the catalysts. The oxygen vacancy properties of UiO-66 and CeO2, as well as the large specific surface and porous properties of UiO-66 promoted the capture and absorb of CO2, thus promoted the reaction. In addition, the catalyst showed favorable reusability, attributing to the excellent hydrothermal stability nature of the UiO-66 and CeO2. coredata.dc:description: In this study, UiO-66 @CeO2 composites was prepared by loading CeO2 nanoparticles on the surface of UiO-66 using precipitation method, and the effect of CeO2 loading on the catalytic direct reaction of CO2 and methanol into dimethyl carbonate (DMC) was investigated. XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, FT-IR, XPS, SEM and TEM were used to investigate the physical and chemical properties of UiO-66 @CeO2. The results showed that the framework structure of UiO-66 benefit the high dispersion of CeO2, while the loading of CeO2 provided more oxygen vacancies, which promoted the capture and absorb of CO2, thus promoted the reaction synergistically. Among which, UiO-66 @CeO2-60 showed best activity, with the highest DMC formation rate of 2.84 mmol·g−1·h−1 (yield: 2.27%) within 4 h of reaction time under the optimum conditions. In addition, the catalyst also showed favorable reusability, maintaining ∼90% of catalytic efficiency with 4 reuse cycles compared the fresh ones.
coredata.dc:title: Directly synthesis of dimethyl carbonate from CO2 and methanol over UiO-66 @CeO2 Catalyst
